data.q: Which of the following is the correct way to create an object in JavaScript?
data.e: Using object literal `{}` is the most common and correct way to create an object.

data.q: How do you access the property `name` of an object `user`?
data.e: Dot notation (`user.name`) is the standard way to access object properties.

data.q: Which statement about JavaScript objects is TRUE?
data.e: Objects are reference types, so variables store references to them.

data.q: What does the `this` keyword refer to inside an object method?
o: The object that owns the method
data.e: `this` refers to the object on which the method is called.

data.q: Which method is used to add a property to an object's prototype?
data.e: Properties are added to a prototype via `Constructor.prototype.propertyName`.

data.q: What is a prototype in JavaScript?
o: An object from which other objects inherit properties
data.e: A prototype is an object that provides shared properties and methods via inheritance.

data.q: Which operator is used to check if an object inherits a property?
data.e: The `in` operator checks both own and inherited properties.

o: Checks if an object has a property
Checks if an object is an instance of a constructor
Checks if two objects are equal
Checks if an object is iterable
data.e: `instanceof` checks whether an object exists in a constructor's prototype chain.

data.q: Which built-in method returns an object's prototype?
data.e: `Object.getPrototypeOf()` safely returns the prototype of an object.

data.q: What happens when a property is not found on an object?
o: JavaScript looks up the prototype chain
data.e: JavaScript searches for the property up the prototype chain until it is found or ends.
